body: Yes, you are right. And I'm actually running the job using a monoid to compute the avg. But so far I've not been able to come up with the proper monoid for percentile :(

https://github.com/twitter/algebird/blob/develop/algebird-core/src/main/scala/com/twitter/algebird/QTree.scala

Hi, @sprsquish. I tried doing so and I've run into a quite nasty problem. Running bin/web causes following StackOverflowError:

```
[info] Running com.twitter.zipkin.web.Main 
[error] java.lang.StackOverflowError
[error]     at scala.runtime.AbstractFunction0.<init>(AbstractFunction0.scala:12)
[error]     at scala.runtime.AbstractFunction0$mcV$sp.<init>(AbstractFunction0.scala:12)
[error]     at com.twitter.server.Closer$$anonfun$closeOnExit$1.<init>(Closer.scala:29)
[error]     at com.twitter.server.Closer$class.closeOnExit(Closer.scala:29)
[error]     at com.twitter.zipkin.web.Main$.closeOnExit(Main.scala:101)
[error]     at com.twitter.app.App$class.onExit(App.scala:87)
[error]     at com.twitter.zipkin.web.Main$.onExit(Main.scala:101)
[error]     at com.twitter.server.Closer$class.closeOnExit(Closer.scala:29)
[error]     at com.twitter.zipkin.web.Main$.closeOnExit(Main.scala:101)
[error]     at com.twitter.app.App$class.onExit(App.scala:87)
[error]     at com.twitter.zipkin.web.Main$.onExit(Main.scala:101)
```

Bumping plugin works fine, bumping scrooge library causes the error. I had a quick look at the source code and I think it is due to a bug in the new scrooge version.

Not sure why exactly. TwitterServer got an update, along with finagle and util. I just tried revving all of them and it ran.

These are the versions I used:
finagle: 3.13.1
util: 3.13.2
twitter-server: 1.6.1
scrooge: 3.13.0
That makes perfect sense. I've updated the pull request.
thanks!

## 

Jeff Smick
@sprsquish
Sorry it took so long – I opened #374 to fix the tests I broke.
Closed in #373.  Thanks
The newer code is flag based and lets you change databases without recompiling. I don't think all the backends have been fully tested though. The SQL may still fail.

Thanks for the reply Jeff.  Happy to move this to the google group if that is better.

Any thoughts on the sqlite errors?  My thought was that too many spans where coming in asynchronously, and sqlite couldn't handle it.  But I wasn't sure.

I think I am using the "newer code".  My testing was on master, commit 20f148b35ed18fa543cbedbc8ad977de54990b7a from 2 Apr.

When you say flag, do you mean "sqlite-persistent"  on https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-anormdb/src/main/scala/com/twitter/zipkin/util/DBConfig.scala#L54 and https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/blob/master/project/Project.scala#L272?  If so, I don't see how to change backends without changing those values and recompiling.

At the very least, I'd like to try to get unit tests for sqlite (memory and persistent) and h2 (memory and persistent) against the SQL changes I made.  I can test manually against MySQL and Postgres.

I'm not sure about the SQLite issues. How fast were you pushing data into it?

By new code, I meant the new SpanStore: https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-anormdb/src/main/scala/com/twitter/zipkin/storage/anormdb/AnormSpanStore.scala

It's still undocumented, but pretty easy to get working (https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-example/src/main/scala/com/twitter/zipkin/example/Main.scala). 

Better unit tests would be great.

I pushed in about 50 spans/second for 2 seconds.  Got about 8 of those exceptions, but it was hard to tell exactly which spans failed.

I'll take a look at the AnormSpanStore, thanks.  I did notice the SQL was duplicated there and in AnormIndex.  Thanks.
merged

So with the AnormDBSpanStoreFactory, it looks like only the AnormSpanStore and SpanStoreDB are needed from the rest of zipkin-anormdb subproject.  Is that right and what is the plan for the rest of the subproject?  Is there a ticket to refactor out old and unneeded code out of anormdb I can watch?

Thanks

That's correct. The rest will be deprecated, but I don't want to start that until I have excellent documentation for the new way of building and configuring a service.

I've created a milestone to track next steps: https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/issues?milestone=2&state=open
LGTM

Thanks for this @fr0stbyte. Can you make the change against master though? I made some edits on the original PR mostly to match the style of the rest of the project.

I noticed that some code was looking strangely unfamiliar. 
Two questions : 
1. here https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/commit/6107d9b#diff-f70d68ae7ea4c895a87b3be96ca84af6R15 
   why is the trait moved down as an internal type of KafkaProcessor ? Decoder[Option[List[Span]]]] is used somewhere else in the code, plus the implementing collectors would use it. Can we keep it top level and use it throughout the project ? 
2. https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/pull/390/files#diff-edc7ec48aa7cab8b9004553848474e92R22 the flag is a `,` separated sequence of type `a=b`. Without the definition of the flag, how will the system understand `-zipkin.kafka.topics=a=1,b=2,c=3` ?

1. It's never used as a trait. The process doesn't take a `KafkaDecoder` it takes a `Decoder[Option[List[Span]]]` (I think that's the right approach, btw). Having it as a trait doesn't really mean anything. It's used as a type alias, so I made that explicit. 
2. Flag already provides a map type: https://github.com/twitter/util/blob/master/util-app/src/main/scala/com/twitter/app/Flag.scala#L86

Sure, not as a trait but as a type then ? 
Didn't know about the map type, thanks for that.
Types have to be defined inside something. We could put it in a package object, but there's little different between doing that and leaving it where it is.
Got it. Please check the updated diff.
@sprsquish bump
@fr0stbyte hey. sorry. I've been pretty buried. I don't think I'm going to have the change to get to this until next week.

When I try to run the tests for this `bin/sbt zipkin-hbase/test` I get the following:

```
[error] /Users/jeff/workspace/zipkin/oss/zipkin-hbase/src/test/scala/com/twitter/zipkin/storage/hbase/utils/HBaseSpecification.scala:4: HBaseTestingUtility is not a member of org.apache.hadoop.hbase
[error] import org.apache.hadoop.hbase.HBaseTestingUtility
[error]        ^
[error] /Users/jeff/workspace/zipkin/oss/zipkin-hbase/src/test/scala/com/twitter/zipkin/storage/hbase/utils/HBaseSpecification.scala:34: not found: type HBaseTestingUtility
[error]   lazy val sharedUtil = new HBaseTestingUtility()
[error]                             ^
[error] /Users/jeff/workspace/zipkin/oss/zipkin-hbase/src/test/scala/com/twitter/zipkin/storage/hbase/utils/HBaseSpecification.scala:11: not found: type HBaseTestingUtility
[error]   lazy val _util: HBaseTestingUtility = HBaseSpecification.sharedUtil
```

That's another dependency problem. I think it should be fixed by

```
diff --git a/project/Project.scala b/project/Project.scala
index 61c2e9e..c5b2695 100644
--- a/project/Project.scala
+++ b/project/Project.scala
@@ -480,8 +480,10 @@ object Zipkin extends Build {
       "org.apache.hadoop"     % "hadoop-common"         % "2.4.0",
       "org.apache.hbase"      % "hbase"                 % hbaseVersion,
       "org.apache.hbase"      % "hbase-common"          % hbaseVersion,
+      "org.apache.hbase"      % "hbase-common"          % hbaseVersion % "test" classifier("tests") classifier(""),
       "org.apache.hbase"      % "hbase-client"          % hbaseVersion,
       "org.apache.hbase"      % "hbase-client"          % hbaseVersion % "test" classifier("tests") classifier(""),
+      "org.apache.hbase"      % "hbase-server"          % hbaseVersion % "test" classifier("tests") classifier(""),
       "com.google.guava"      % "guava-io"              % "r03" % "test",
       "com.google.protobuf"   % "protobuf-java"         % "2.4.1",
       "org.apache.hadoop"     % "hadoop-core"           % "1.2.1" notTransitive(),
```

I'm having trouble adding an additional resolver to get `hbase-common-0.98.3-hadoop2-tests.jar` since Typesafe doesn't have it in their repo. Once I've got the resolver working (and assuming that the dependency changes in the diff above solve the problem), I'll push a new commit with the changes.

It appears that `com.twitter.common` requires Google guava version 16.  Hadoop's `org.apache.hadoop.util.JvmPauseMonitor` requires a lower version of guava: one which implements the `elapsedMillis()` method. I'm looking into a solution.

For some reason, sbt is only trying the typesafe resolver, and is not trying the `DefaultMavenRepository` resolver as declared in `Project.scala`. Once the artifacts are resolved, the tests pass (at least on my machine). I'll continue trying to get the resolver working.
It appears that there are other tests that are failing occasionally in Travis? There aren't actually any tests for the gems.

@Oscil8 TravisCI hasn't been working reliably for some time and the gem tests don't get run anyway.

I've been completely swamped the last couple weeks and will continue to be for the next couple. I'll take a closer look and pull this in when I can catch my breath. Thanks for the contribution!

I believe this is now fixed in the latest version of the UI.

Agreed.  I had to do this:

```
val conf = HBaseConfiguration.create()
conf.set(HConstants.ZOOKEEPER_QUORUM, storageHost)
conf.set(HConstants.ZOOKEEPER_CLIENT_PORT, storagePort)

val storeBuilder = Store.Builder(
  hbase.StorageBuilder(confOption = Some(conf)),
  hbase.IndexBuilder(confOption = Some(conf))
)
```

I see.
thanks!
